richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Jails, prisons, and detention centers across the United States are inhumane. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As the COVID-19 pandemic laid undeniably bare, these facilities are inherently dehumanizing institutions that negatively impact nearly every aspect of an incarcerated personâ€™s life, from mental and physical health and basic physical security to future opportunities. Approximately one in 30 people are sexually assaulted every year in these institutions. Medical needs are often unmet. Food is contaminated. Vermin infestations are common. Floors and walls are covered in blood, feces, and mucus. Many people are not permitted to visit with their loved ones, and many are deprived of exercise, fresh air, and sunlight. Between 2008 and 2019, more than 7,500 people died in local jails.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These institutions make our communities less safe while magnifying disparities based on race, sexual orientation, gender identity, and religion. Serious racial disparities are baked into nearly every aspect of the criminal-legal system, including who is jailed and imprisoned: Black people are jailed at rates more than three times that of White people, and Black men are imprisoned at a rate of more than five times that of White men. One-third of incarcerated women are lesbian or bisexual, though this group comprises only 3.5 percent of women nationwide. And, while there is little to no information on trans individuals within the criminal-legal system, research has shown extreme bias by police toward transgender-identifying individuals, particularly Black transgender individuals, which disproportionately funnels them into the criminal-legal system. Meanwhile, Muslims are 20 percent of the prison population in certain states, even though they represent less than 2 percent of the U.S. population. And American Indian/Alaska Natives are incarcerated in adult correctional facilities at more than twice the rate of White people.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The time has come to radically reduce prison and jail populations while creating a new system premised on healing, accountability, rehabilitation, and the respect for basic human rights. We must build a world in which people are given the community-based supports they need to survive and thrive.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}
